definition:
Consider the integer 384. Multiplying its digits,
$$3 \times 8 \times 4 = 96$$ and $${{384} \over {96}} = 91.$$

When an integer is divisible by the product of its digits, it’s called a
[*Zuckerman number*]{}. That is, given $m$ is the number of digits of
$n$ and $d_x$ (for $x \le k$) is an integer of $n$,

$${\prod_{i = 1}^m d_i}|n$$

All 1-digit numbers and the base number itself are Zuckerman numbers.

It is possible for an integer to be divisible by its multiplicative
digital root and yet not be a Zuckerman number because it doesn’t divide
its first digit product evenly (for example, 1728 in base 10 has
multiplicative digital root 2 but is not divisible by
$1 \times 7 \times 2 \times 8 = 112$). The reverse is also possible (for
example, 384 is divisible by 96, as shown above, but clearly not by its
multiplicative digital root 0).

[2]{} J. J. Tattersall, [*Elementary number theory in nine chapters*]{},
p. 86. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press (2005)
